items.content_html:
This PR adds Chrome and Edge support for AudioContext outputLatency.
Source: https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/8866a84d12e96c5fbb85ab8258f6fa80cb833843

FYI @hoch
items.title: Add Chrome & Edge support for AudioContext outputLatency

items.content_html:
This uses the build-time mirroring recently implemented:
#16401

The resulting build/data.json is unchanged.
items.title: Use "mirror" for AbortController data

items.content_html:
FF101 CSSStyleSheet supports constructible stylesheets in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1644102

What that essentially means is that layout.css.constructable-stylesheets.enabled is now true by default. I've therefore added a new version for support on the three affected methods for firefox and also for firefox android. I've marked the old version with the flag as version removed.

Other docs work can be tracked in mdn/content#16624 (comment)
items.title: FF101 CSSStyleSheet supports constructible stylesheets

items.content_html:
The prioritised scheduling API was mostly present in BCD and I added FF101 updates in #16177.

BUT, access to the API is via the scheduler property on the global object - e.g. this or window on main thread. This adds BCD entry for Window.scheduler.

@queengooborg Question for you. The spec actually adds this to WindowOrWorderGlobalScope mixin which we don't document. One place obviously that goes is Window (as documented here). But where do I add the worker entries both for BCD and docs - this could be the top level scope objects (all of them) or somewhere else. Advice appreciated!
items.title: Window.scheduler

Related content update is in Manifest theme key update #16568 .

Motivation

To document the changes made in Bug 1750932 Allow themes to override global color scheme heuristics.

Test results and supporting details

Passed npm test

items.title: Update position.json

items.content_html:
The ie.json browser file still says that IE11 is "current".

This commit changes the status to "retired" given the formal desktop app retirement coming up on June 15 2022.

This PR should, in theory, wait until June 15 to get merged, although I don't think there's a risk with merging it earlier than this.
items.title: Marking IE11 as retired

items.content_html:
Per https://w3c.github.io/selection-api/#selectstart-event the event target of "selectstart" events is a Node, which will be either an Element or a Text node.

Per https://w3c.github.io/selection-api/#selectionchange-event the event target can be Document, HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextareaElement.

Part of #7545.
items.title: Adapt selectstart/selectionchange events to new event structure

items.content_html:
This PR updates the release info for the Oculus browser based upon the support page: https://developer.oculus.com/documentation/web/browser-release-notes/#oculus-browser-162

Note that I have no clue which engine it is or what the release date was, as there's not a lot of public information about the Oculus browser. I also removed the entry for "17.0" since there's no mention of it.
items.title: Update Oculus browser release info

items.content_html:
Summary

EXT_texture_compression_bptc and EXT_texture_compression_rgtc were added in Chrome 82.

Test results and supporting details

Verified that it works on my machine in Chrome and Edge latest. This is the Chromium commit that added support: https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commits?commit=de2f6f382d1d4371c69b5359eb2f2763fe6df427
items.title: EXT_texture_compression_bptc and EXT_texture_compression_rgtc added in Chrome 82.

items.content_html:
Summary

HTMLMediaElement.volume does not work on iOS browsers. While it returns a value and can be set, the value is always 1, and setting the value has no effect on the actual volume of the media.

I've chosen to reflect this by setting partial_implementation on the safari_ios browser along with clarifying notes.

Test results and supporting details

This app was tested on Safari iOS 11 - 15: https://0680re.csb.app/. The "Mute (Volume)" button attempts to programmatically set the volume to 0.

There isn't a lot of official documentation around this. There is a reference to this behavior in https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AudioVideo/Conceptual/Using_HTML5_Audio_Video/Device-SpecificConsiderations/Device-SpecificConsiderations.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009523-CH5-SW1; however, that doc is quite old, and is only concerned with Safari, even though other iOS browsers (like Chrome) also behave the same way.

This issue has been observed by others many times:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12553757/html5-ios-volumechange-event-not-fired
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71308806/ionic-htmlaudioelement-cant-change-volume-on-ios
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59417075/javascript-detect-if-volume-can-be-set

Related issues

This was reported in #12001; however, that issue also brings up Chrome on iOS, which this PR doesn't support.

Additional Info & Questions

As mentioned above, this limitation on volume is an iOS level restriction, and applies to all browsers running on iOS, not just Safari (which is all this PR covers).

The compat data does not track, for example, Chrome on iOS (I'm curious as to the reason for this), so even if this PR were merged, the docs would still have no indication that setting volume would not work on Chrome on iOS. I'd like some input on whether I should also (in addition to this PR) open a PR in the MDN docs repo that discusses this behavior of volume on iOS more in-depth.
items.title: Change HTMLMediaElement.volume support for safari_ios to partial_implementation

items.content_html: This PR simplifies the data for the font-size CSS property for Internet Explorer. The partial_implementation statement came from the wiki migration, but there's no explanation of why, and other rem value properties in BCD don't have a partial_implementation statement.
items.title: Simplify IE data for font-size rem values

items.content_html: This PR is a subset of #16051 that adds spec URLs for the HTML APIs.
items.title: Add spec URLs for HTML APIs
